185798431.review: My favourite Fallout game, Fallout: New Vegas combines the open world exploration of Fallout 3 with the elaborate quests and storytelling of the classic Fallouts. New Vegas expands upon Fallout 3 with more weapons, more perks, more crafting recipes, new unarmed/melee special attacks, a proper food/drink system, an improved armour system that reintroduces Damage Threshold (DT), ammo variants, weapon modding, and even card/gambling minigames. Most importantly, New Vegas has superb writing: world-building is highly consistent; everything has a proper lore explanation; factions are expertly-designed and have well-defined cultures/beliefs; quests have multiple solutions; and the story has many deviations depending on your choices. New Vegas' four story DLCs (Dead Money, Honest Hearts, Old World Blues, and Lonesome Road) are also some of the best DLC in gaming history. Make sure to buy the Ultimate Edition of this game, as New Vegas is not a complete game without all of its DLC. You'll also likely have to install performance mods, as the game crashes constantly on modern systems.

185789983.review: This is in my opinion the best first person RPG ever made. Obsidian really knocked it out of the park with this one. The world of Fallout is one of my favorite to visit and this game has plenty to explore. Something to note is that much of this game is set in an open desert which I admit isn't super visually stimulating but there's plenty of unique spots to find within the desert and it makes finding towns and settlements that much more enjoyable but your mileage may vary. In terms of gameplay, this game does show its age in more ways than one, however I don't think this takes away from the game at all. Specifically the shooting in this game is a little janky and hard to get used to but personally I feel this adds to the experience because of V.A.T.S., the sort of auto aim mechanic in the game. Personally I don't have many issues aiming as I've gotten used to the game but for newcomers it can be a learning curve. In terms of the RPG aspect, this game passes with flying colors. You can customize your character a variety of ways and (especially without the DLC raising the level cap) it rewards you for doing multiple playthroughs by trying out different builds and perks. As for the story, there are multiple factions to engage with and the game gives you almost complete freedom on how you choose to deal with all of them. You can even reject them all and form your own path. The soundtrack is also phenominal from both the in-game radio and the overworld music. One minute you'll be listening to classic jazz and country tracks, the next you'll be listening to the creepy ambience as you explore a new cave or abandoned building. The voice acting also leaves little to be desired, with stellar performances all around for basically every character in the game. You will find that many characters sound quite similar, with voices like Liam O'brien and Yuri Lowenthal being used all over the game. This might detract from your immersion but personally I think they do an excellent job with all of their roles and make most of them sound unique. The main game of Fallout New Vegas is excellent in every way I could think of and delivers on everything I want from an RPG. That being said I found the DLCs to leave a little to be desired, especially Dead Money. A fair warning for new players, if you go into a DLC area (aside from the Lonesome Road) you will not be able to return to the main game until it is finished and all of these areas are very high level. The stories of these DLCs also continue and expand on much of the story of New Vegas's base game so I would advise to play them after finishing the game for the best experience. Dead money has a great story but is very flawed. If you did not level any melee abilities before going in, you will most likely have a hard time playing catch up because the guns found here are either not good or are hard to come by. It also has a mute character who uses sign language. Cool idea, horribly implemented. Honest Hearts is some more good old fashioned New Vegas to run around in and I personally found it very enjoyable and it expands well on the main story. Old World Blues is the wackiest of the bunch by far. Many new unique weapons to find and some great quality of life upgrades for your playthrough. I didn't really care for the story, the main characters will talk at you for literally almost 20 minutes straight with nothing interesting to say other than "funny" fart jokes to keep you entertained. Thankfully there is an option to skip all this dialogue which I have used to great use on my many playthroughs. Finally, The Lonesome Road is a great capstone for the game. Your mileage with the story in this one may vary, but the gameplay in this new area is fantastic with many new challenging enemies and awesome areas to explore. With that being said, I do not think the DLC is mandatory to play to enjoy New Vegas to it's fullest. I think the best part of the game is the main game and I often don't even go into the DLC unless I'm doing a full run. If you've been on the fence about trying this one, or even just want a good game to play, play it. It will be worth your time and money. 10/10

185691055.review:
Ah, Fallout: New Vegas, where every day is a gamble, and your luck stat might determine if you survive a gecko attack or accidentally barter away your pants for a bottle cap. This game is like a post-apocalyptic buffet: radioactive, unpredictable, and guaranteed to give you heartburn—in the best way possible.

From the moment you wake up with a massive headache and a bad case of bullet-to-the-brain syndrome, you know you’re in for a wild ride. The opening scene is iconic: a robot cowboy digs you out of the dirt, and a guy in a checkered suit shoots you in the face. Classic Vegas hospitality.

The characters are unforgettable. There's Boone, the broody sniper who would probably win "Most Likely to Stare at the Mojave Sunset Dramatically." Then there's Mr. House, a reclusive billionaire who’s basically Howard Hughes with more robots and fewer tissues. And let’s not forget Yes Man, the cheerful AI that’s suspiciously cool with you taking over the world.

The gameplay? Chef’s kiss. You can negotiate peace between factions, become a master of diplomacy... or just punch Deathclaws in the face with spiked knuckles. The choice is yours. Oh, and the glitches? Think of them as Bethesda’s love letters to you. Sure, your companion might float into the sky or you might accidentally fall through the map into the abyss, but hey, it’s all part of the charm.

The factions are the real stars here. You’ve got the NCR, who are basically your nerdy cousins trying to bring order to chaos. Then there’s Caesar’s Legion, who thought, “Hey, what if Ancient Rome, but terrible?” And of course, the New Vegas Strip itself, where you can gamble, get rich, and immediately blow it all on energy weapons.

The game’s moral dilemmas really make you think. Like, should I nuke a town of innocent people or help an old ghoul live his astronaut dreams? And why do I feel so bad every time I steal a single potato from a rundown shack?

In summary, Fallout: New Vegas is like the ultimate road trip through a radioactive wasteland with a backpack full of questionable decisions. The only thing better than playing it is realising you’ve just spent 200 hours deciding between helping the NCR or ruling the wasteland like a benevolent tyrant.

10/10 would get shot in the head and chase a man in a checkered suit across the desert again. Viva New Vegas!

185610759.review:
I'm sure it's all been said before, so I'll keep this brief.

This game has some issues.  In my last playthrough, I saved very often because I crashed about once every 60-120 minutes of play.  Suffice it to say the game was so enjoyable that I was willing to tolerate 45+ crashes-to-desktop over the course of a ~60-70 hour playthrough.

There is a wealth of mods available for this game - it's possible some might improve the stability of the program; I am a bit of a purist, so I rarely use mods in this kind of game.

I highly recommend this game.  It has brought me much joy over the years, and I believe that unless you hate RPGs, you are likely to enjoy this game and find it to be worth your time.

185288834.review:
This game is a certified hood classic. It’s one of the best open world rpgs ever made. The story is very well written and there’s a lot of interesting lore. There’s tons of unique characters, weapons and quests. The character customization is good, and you can build your character in a bunch of different ways. This, along with the 4 different endings makes the game highly re-playable. The graphics aren’t amazing, but this is a game that came out in 2010 and it’s using Bethesda’s old gamebryo engine. Lastly I’ll touch on the combat: the gunplay is improved from fallout 3 because you can aim down sights. It’s still not as great as fallout 4’s, but it works. You’ll be using VATS a lot of the time anyway (a combat system that involves pausing the gameplay and targeting enemies to perform an auto attack) which is pretty fun. There is also good enemy variety which I enjoyed. Overall, this is a “must play” game. Your PC can most likely run it pretty well, too. 

I give this game a 9/10 on the goldy review scale.

185244309.review:
Fallout: New Vegas has easily earned its spot as my favorite singleplayer game of all time. The story itself is extremely enjoyable (both base game and the dlcs), the individual locations and areas each have a lot to offer which each one having unique items, unique enemies, or lore that otherwise you may have missed. On the other hand, the overall landscape feels very bland at times, and since you're unable to sprint without mods it can often feel like a running simulator. Regardless, the mechanics in this game feel much better than Fallout 3, 4, or 76 (only other games I've played) and I feel like the gameplay always stays exciting. It is also extremely important to note that [b]without mods the game tends to crash. A lot.[/b] At least in my experience.

8.7/10

Si te gustan los juegos de rol o post-apocalipticos con buena historia, decisiones importantes y un mundo que te invita a explorar, Fallout New Vegas es un título que no deberías perderte.

Calificación: 9/10

185131366.review:
Fallout New Vegas is a continuation and proper sequel to the events of Fallout 1 and 2. And no Todd, the events of the TV show arent canon to those games. 
1.Marcus, once a part of the Master's Super Mutant Army, is now running his own town again up in the mountains called Jacobstown. Named after a friend of his that was part of the Brotherhood of Steel, the two of them traveled together for a ways before having to split up. 
2.Davidson, a nightkin, is one of the few that you can talk to that wont immidiately kill you on sight if you havent killed any of the other Nightkin at the RepCONN launch site during the Come Fly with Me quest. 
3.Anderson is a guy you can meet near the Apartments in Freeside that has a quest where you can either turn him into the NCR for siphoning water to the crops there, or aid him in lying to the NCR and helping Freeside and the surrounding areas. 
4. You learn that Chomps daughter Melissa is part of the Great Khans and she'll back you up after doing a quest early on when you need to confront Pappa Khan and getting him to break off the Alliance with Caesar's Legion. 
i could ramble on more on the quests. I remember more of what i did in New Vegas, then i do in Fallout 3 outside of meeting the Enclave and blowing up Megaton. I recommend this game to those that care about Fallout and the OG games. 
Bethesda, as TwentySide aka Shamus Young would say, NEVER understood Fallout's themes at all. If you want to see a proper breakdown of the Amazon show, check out the channels Creetosis and BCheezySon on Youtube.

185039491.review:
This is my first Fallout game and I'm glad it is, 

I love the story it's full of plot twists, side quests are left and right and the dialogue options are hilarious and vary depending on your skill points, I really like the fact that there are many factions in the game and each with their own quests giving you the option to either be their friend / enemy or neutral, so you can replay the game and each time you choose a different faction resulting in a totally different story. Also don't get me started on the soundtrack, the radio is ALWAYS on (as it should).
My only problem is that the game freshly installed is full of glitches and it crashes sometimes with long loading screens, but this problem is quickly fixed with a couple mods you can install easily (there is a guide on steam called "New Vegas 2024 Essential Modding Guide" I used it and it worked great).

I've already spent 70 hours on this game and I'm pretty sure I won't stop there.
I really think you should play this game, you'll love it.

185023839.review:
"Fallout: New Vegas" é um RPG de ação pós-apocalíptico desenvolvido pela Obsidian Entertainment e publicado pela Bethesda Softworks. Lançado em 2010, o jogo se passa em um mundo devastado por uma guerra nuclear, mais especificamente no deserto de Mojave, em torno da cidade de New Vegas.

Jogabilidade e Desafios para Iniciantes
Uma das marcas registradas de "Fallout: New Vegas" é a sua jogabilidade desafiadora, especialmente para novos jogadores. O jogo oferece um mundo vasto e aberto, cheio de perigos e oportunidades de exploração.

Mecânicas de Sobrevivência
Uma característica notável de "Fallout: New Vegas" é o modo Hardcore. Neste modo, as mecânicas de sobrevivência são acentuadas, tornando a experiência de jogo mais realista e desafiadora:

Necessidades Básicas: O jogador deve gerenciar fome, sede e cansaço. Ignorar essas necessidades pode levar a penalidades severas e até a morte.

Municação com Peso: Ao contrário do modo normal, onde munições não têm peso, no modo Hardcore, todas as munições adicionam peso ao inventário, exigindo um gerenciamento cuidadoso dos recursos.

Cura Realista: Itens de cura, como Stimpaks, não curam instantaneamente. Em vez disso, a cura ocorre ao longo do tempo, o que adiciona um elemento de estratégia ao combate.

Desafios de Jogabilidade
A curva de aprendizado em "Fallout: New Vegas" pode ser íngreme para iniciantes. Alguns dos principais desafios incluem:

Exploração Perigosa: O deserto de Mojave é cheio de criaturas hostis, radiação e bandidos. Navegar por esse ambiente requer cautela e preparação.

Combate: O sistema de combate permite tanto o uso de armas de fogo quanto de combate corpo a corpo. A precisão e a gestão de recursos são cruciais para sobreviver aos encontros.

Decisões Morais e de Facções: O jogador se depara com várias facções e personagens, cada um com suas próprias agendas. As decisões podem ter consequências significativas, influenciando alianças e inimigos.

História e Enredo
Em "Fallout: New Vegas", você assume o papel do Courier, um mensageiro que sobrevive a uma tentativa de assassinato. O enredo envolve uma complexa teia de intrigas políticas e lutas territoriais entre facções como a New California Republic (NCR), Caesar's Legion e Mr. House.

A história é profunda e ramificada, oferecendo múltiplos finais baseados nas escolhas do jogador. Essa liberdade de escolha é um dos aspectos mais aclamados do jogo.

Conclusão
"Fallout: New Vegas" é uma obra-prima que combina uma narrativa envolvente com mecânicas de sobrevivência robustas e uma jogabilidade desafiadora. Para os iniciantes, o jogo pode ser implacável, mas a sensação de conquista ao superar seus desafios é incomparável. A riqueza do mundo aberto e a profundidade das decisões morais tornam cada jornada única e memorável.

184910153.review:
This is game is fun, but... there are some problems with it. 

First, it crashes often. With my current system specs ([i]shown in profile[/i]) I should have NO problems running this game. I'll play for 20 to 30 minutes, then it'll crash. Then I'll close both the game and Steam entirely, reload everything, and then play for 3 to 4 hours straight with no issues. Then suddenly it'll freeze up when entering a new area. Sometimes, it'll unfreeze itself and I can play another hour or so, and then sometimes it just closes itself entirely without warning. 

[b]This is getting very annoying...[/b]

Second, I've done numerous quests so far and should have earned no less than 12 different achievements on the achievement list. So far I only have one achievement. One! [b]W...T...F...?!?[/b]

Third, I'm still going to play the game, but I may have to MOD it to avoid these problems, and I should [b]NOT[/b] have to mod it to be able to play it.

Finally, I cannot recommend this game at this time until these issues are fixed, as I purchased this game AND all of the DLC for it as well, in the hopes of being able to enjoy it, as I've been a big Fallout fan for years now.

184700961.review:
Eu estou recomendando esse jogo, pois tenho 89 horas nele, e não é possível passar tanto tempo num jogo single player sem ter se entretido. E isso significa que ele vale a pena, mesmo que pessoalmente eu tenha me decepcionado. 

Eu já havia jogado Fallout 1 e Fallout 3, sendo o terceiro um dos jogos mais legais e imersivos que eu já joguei e estava vibrante para este que é tido por basicamente toda a comunidade como o melhor Fallout. E eu entendo, ele é sempre elogiado como um bom RPG, mas veja só, a história é importante para mim e aqui ela não me empolgou.

A trama principal perde todo o mistério quando entendemos o que está acontecendo e sinceramente não acho muito incentivador o que temos pela frente. As side-quests são umas mais sem graça que as outras. Em Fallout 3 tínhamos tantas side-quests com histórias ricas, dava gosto explorar a Westland, aqui nenhuma me marcou. 

Essa coisa de facção era tipo trocar o ruim pelo pior, pois temos duas grandes facções brigando que são os Ceasars: um bando de psicopata de saia, e os milicos, e francamente eu não suporto milico.

E temos as dlcs, que novamente em Fallout 3 cada uma era extremamente diferente da outra, com sua própria personalidade e lore, mas aqui... Começando pela queridinha do povo: Lonesome Road — é chata, linear e o antagonista/coadjuvante da história é um pé no saco, tedioso e filosofo de boteco.  

Daí vamos para Old World Blues, a dlc "engraçadinha" o povo gosta disso só porque os robôs fazem piadas sexuais bem bobinhas, pois tem as quests mais irritantes de ir e vir, — não tem nenhum motivo bom para explorar o mapa além de ir procurar porcarias. Tem umas quests tão repetitivas, que eu pensei que estava jogando um MMO. Mas olhe lá: dá umas armas boas...

Para não dizer que tudo era horrível, temos Honest Hearts, que é uma dlc bacana, nada incrível, mas bacana, foi um ar fresco, foi divertido e trouxe uma estética mais selvagem para o jogo, no entanto é a mais pequenas de todas.

E por fim Dead Money, a pior coisa do mundo, que dlc lixo. É uma expansão de Survivor Horror, com tudo possível que vai te irritar. Você tem uma coleira fodida no pescoço que explode ao entrar em contato com a sintonia de radios ou alto falantes. Eu tive que usar um mod que era uma pistola que neutralizava essa merda ao ficar clicando no gatilho E MESMO ASSIM ESSA COLEIRA ME IRRITOU MUITO. Eu fico imaginando as centenas de vezes que eu teria morrido se não fosse por esse mod. E não é só isso, tem uma caralhada de armadilhas, gás venenoso e o escambal, a única coisa que se salva é a história que é tragica e bonitinha.

Enfim, é um dos jogos já feitos. Me entreteve, mas eu ficava esperando um climax que não veio em nenhuma quest, em nada. Eu literalmente cheguei no nivél 50 desse jogo, nem em Fallout 3 eu maximizei tudo. A quest final não se compara ao final de Fallout 3, mas que foi bom botar os milicos pra correr foi! 

Eu queria dar review neutra, mas assim, A MAIORIA AMA ESSE JOGO, então a sua chance de gostar é GRANDE. Tem gameplay legal, embora não me tenha dado vontade de explorar a MOJAVE.

184658232.review:
Fallout: New Vegas, c’est un chef-d’œuvre du RPG. Ce jeu a une âme, une ambiance unique, et des choix qui comptent vraiment. Même après toutes ces années, il reste une référence pour moi.

Ce que j’adore :
-L’écriture : Les dialogues, les personnages, les factions… Tout est incroyablement bien écrit. Chaque choix a des conséquences, et on sent vraiment le poids de nos décisions.
-L’ambiance : Le désert du Mojave est fascinant à explorer. Les musiques, les lieux, et même les petites histoires cachées rendent le monde immersif.
-La liberté : On peut rejoindre qui on veut, trahir, aider, ou juste se balader en solitaire. C’est toi qui décides de ton aventure.

Les petits défauts :
-Les bugs : Comme souvent avec les jeux Bethesda/Obsidian, il y a pas mal de bugs. Certains sont drôles, d’autres un peu moins… Mais les mods aident beaucoup à corriger ça.
-Le gameplay : Le système de combat est un peu rigide, surtout comparé à des jeux plus récents. Heureusement, l’écriture et l’exploration compensent largement.

En résumé, Fallout: New Vegas, c’est un jeu qui te marque. Si tu aimes les RPG où tes choix comptent vraiment, avec une ambiance post-apocalyptique inoubliable, fonce. C’est une expérience qui vaut chaque minute passée dessus.

Fallout: New Vegas Review – A Post-Apocalyptic Gem

🌟 Rating: Masterpiece 🌟

Fallout: New Vegas isn’t just a game; it’s an experience that stands tall in the Fallout franchise. I LOVED the faction system in this game—it’s one of the best features ever implemented in an RPG. The ability to align yourself with different factions, each with its own unique ideologies, goals, and consequences, makes every decision feel impactful and meaningful. It adds so much depth and replayability that no two playthroughs are the same.

The ammo system was another standout for me. The variety of ammo types, from armor-piercing to hollow-point, added a layer of strategy that I sorely missed in Fallout 4. Being able to adapt your loadout for specific enemies or situations felt incredibly immersive and made combat so much more rewarding. I truly hope future Fallout games bring this feature back—it’s a game-changer.

While Fallout 4 was great in its own way, I couldn’t help but wish it had taken more inspiration from New Vegas. The storytelling, the freedom of choice, and the intricate systems in New Vegas set a gold standard for the series. Bethesda, take notes—this is how you do a Fallout game!

If you haven’t played New Vegas, you’re missing out on one of the most immersive, choice-driven RPGs ever made. It’s a masterpiece that every Fallout fan—and every gamer—should experience. Viva New Vegas! 🎰☢️

剧情方面主线伟大无需多言！支线剧情也一个比一个荒诞有趣。说说DLC吧，目前为止DLC玩过最多次也是印象最深的是死钱，世外桃源保留着战前虚假的繁华，专情之人为情所困，贪婪之人毁了自己。第一次打结局的时候赌场马上就要炸了，我狂塞金块整理背包，为了多带点金块出去当时折腾了很长时间，吃药整理背包，差点坏档，但是事后想起来，感觉自己的贪婪真的太好笑了，那些金块有什么用呢？哪怕在游戏里，最珍贵的应该是那些独一无二的战前科技，而不是只能换成瓶盖的金块。但是为了那些超重的金块，我读档了无数次，感觉死钱的剧情就在我身上重演了似的.......整个DLC没有说教也没有刻意让玩家去进行道德选择，只是在游戏过程中让玩家自己寻找和体会这个故事的细节，这种克制真的在游戏编剧中太少见太少见了

184368219.review:
A bit of background: I played about 150 hours of fallout 4 in high school as my first experience with a fallout game, and I thoroughly enjoyed my time with it. I had no knowledge of the game series outside of that specific iteration, which is probably why I was able to look past the glorified chore simulator that fallout 4 is at it's core.

I was told by my friends that New Vegas is not only the best fallout, but one of the best games of all time. I was really expecting something phenominal; the game only half delivered. The writing, quest design, and story in this game are all great, almost every quest I played had a completely different trajectory depending on the actions I took. The factions had much deeper ideas and flaws than they do in Fo4, and the characters have some pretty remarkable variety. 

However, I played this game on an MSI sword 17 with windows 11. The game is incredibly buggy and unstable, and it's essentially unplayable without a host of mods to stabilize it. It took me well over 30 hours before I figured out the combination of mods that worked for me. (NV script extender, 4gb RAM patch, NV anti-crash, plus all the individual components for the just vanilla sprint mod. I installed NVSE and 4GB straight into the game files, and used VortexMods to install the rest.) It's really crummy that bethesda/obsidian won't release compatibility patches to fix their games over time, and instead rely on their players to fix their broken games for them. Also, I found some of the gameplay mechanics in the DLC's to be tedious and overly obnoxious so I didn't spend much time playing them. 

Overall I would reccomend the base game to fans of RPG's, so long as they're comfortable with the idea of modding.

184359042.review: This is a great game, I consider it to be the best Fallout game, and I'm sure many would agree. Hell, I think if the developers had the time and resources to fully develop this game it would have been one of the best games of all time. It is a return to the West Coast, where it actually makes sense to have Centaurs and Super Mutants running around, and it builds on the world of the first two games in so many ways. In this game, there are functioning governments that compete with each other, uncompromising their vision for a better world, and the beautiful part of this game is that there is no strictly good or evil option. All these different and conflicting ideologies, and none of them are without merit. In the end, you make the choice who rules over the Mojave. And it will always be your choice.

184348488.review:
O primeiro Fallout que zerei (ainda vou jogar os outros) é um jogo fenomenal, com um texto impressionante, especialmente nas DLCs Honest Hearts e Lonesome Road. Gosto do fato de o jogo permitir que você brinque com as possibilidades: decidir quem vive, quem morre, e quando realizar os objetivos X ou Y.

Os companions, mesmo sendo simples e repetindo bastante as falas, são espetaculares e têm camadas. Isso é algo que falta em Skyrim, por exemplo. Além disso, o fato de Fallout: New Vegas não ter quests geradas proceduralmente me deixa muito feliz.

Porém, acho o jogo longe de ser perfeito. Ele crasha bastante, a gunplay sem mods é horrível (e acredite, você vai atirar muito neste jogo), e há outros problemas, como não poder correr de verdade, a IA que frequentemente buga, entre outros. Esses defeitos podem ser resolvidos com mods, mas ninguém é obrigado a consertar um jogo mal otimizado como Fallout: New Vegas.

Ainda assim, se você tiver paciência, o jogo pode se tornar bem prazeroso. Em resumo, é um jogo muito bom, mas com muitos defeitos. Se você busca uma história com um texto impecável, vai encontrar aqui. Mas, se os problemas técnicos te desanimam e você não está disposto a corrigir nada, também vai se deparar com eles.

Para finalizar, queria encerrar com a frase que mais me marcou neste jogo:
"War. War never changes. Men do, through the roads they walk." – Ron Perlman

184299562.review:
So far my experience has been very awkward.

First, I had issues with the resolution... that's fine, I had to restart and change resolution outside of the game. What this didn't fix was the insane cursor speed that happens within menus. I don't know why its so fast, and I can't change it. Only in menus, I can play the game just fine.

Second, I have crashed 6 times. The loading screens are very short so far, which is nice... but when I first launch the game there's a chance I can't get to the menu at all. The game thinks so freaking hard, my CPU is at 100% utilization, and I can't do anything on my PC until it decides It wants to launch or not.

Now actual gameplay... I have seen a vast expanse of desert, with some more desert. I have fought 7 coyotes, something around 8 geckos, 2 wild dogs, and about 1000000000 scorpions. I saw a deathclaw, but it was stuck in the floor and I decided not to try and fight it at level 2. I finally found NPCs outside of the tiny ass town they start you in, after walking around 100 feet of invisible walls... finally found some humans to kill.

I managed to do around 4 quests for what I assume is a faction of criminals, mainly because they were the only people I could find who didn't have one line of dialogue. Finally I get to another town, more NPCs to talk to... only they won't talk. I mean, we had a conversation, but they were all mute. I got the info I needed, and suddenly the NPCs all draw their weapons and start walking really slowly towards the far end of the building. Dunno what that was about, but it looked like a brain worm took over or something. I decided to leave, since the building was boring and hardly anyone had something interesting to say. Big mistake...

I touched the door to exit the building... I stared at the door. I tried to move my cursor... Great, so it froze. I'll go make some tea and come back... maybe it will be fixed. Nope. 20 minutes later because I got side tracked... I had to close the program that claimed it was responding.

So to summarize... so far I have experienced an utter lack of things to do.
- The slowest character I have ever played.
-As far as I can tell... there is no sprint.
- Mostly invisible walls and empty nothingness
- Insanely boring dialogue from the pitiful number of NPCs I actually managed to find.
- Really bad voice acting. Everyone sounds tired and apathetic. Even when they are making threats.
- Severe stability issues, including weirdly high cursor speeds in the menus. Freezing, and crashing.
- Bethesda shenanigans
- Boredom and frustration.

I want to enjoy this game, or at least give it a chance... but it's really making this hard. I guess it might not run well on modern hardware, so that should be taken into consideration if you're looking to try it. Either that or my brand new PC is already a sack of crap.

184088069.review:
What can I say about Fallout New Vegas? It stands out as my all-time favorite game without a doubt. The journey from being a simple mail couior to becoming the ruler of the expansive and vibrant wasteland of Vegas is nothing short of exhilarating. The game offers an incredible experience that keeps you engaged and wanting more, making it a true gem in the gaming world.

Whether you choose to align with the NCR or the nefarious Caesar's Legion, the game presents a plethora of activities to immerse yourself in. From confronting drug addicts on the bustling Strip to battling mutated roaches in secluded caves, the variety of quests and encounters is staggering. The freedom to explore and make choices in this richly crafted world feels almost limitless, ensuring that every player can find their own unique adventure.

The only real drawback I encountered was some difficulty getting the game to run smoothly on Windows 11. However, aside from that minor hiccup, I wholeheartedly recommend Fallout New Vegas to anyone who hasn't yet experienced the Fallout series or an open-world game. Its captivating storytelling and diverse gameplay make it a must-play for both newcomers and seasoned gamers alike.

If the gameplay doesn't quite meet your expectations, which I find hard to believe, this game is still nearly worth buying just to explore its world and enjoy some fantastic music. After all, who can resist the smooth sounds of Frank Sinatra or Dean Martin?

184078890.review:
This is one of the best RPGs of all time and probably the best game in the Fallout series.  After 14 years, playing the game today still gives a great experience, although encountered crashing a pack of times.  

The story is rich and explorable areas are huge.  After 100 hours into the game, I still have lots of areas haven't been to and many quests not experienced.  Most of the quests have multiple ways to handle and there are consequences.  Followers could take action without your instruction so beware.  

The combat system is quite unique.  You can play either as FPS / action game or strategic game.  Both are viable.  

Achievements are overall very doable.  GRA achievements and collection related achievements are probably the most difficult ones.  Hardcore mode is more tedious so better to do hardcore in the second run.

Overall this is a must play for single player who love story rich games.

I am 14 years late to the party on this game, and I'm so glad I finally played it. I've played Fallout 3 and 4, and I honestly think New Vegas is now my favorite in the series. 

Decisions feel, and are, important in this game. I really felt like I was able to roleplay into a very specific type of character and see those decisions out to the end. 

In many RPGS I find myself skipping through mindless dialogue trees and disengaging from the weak plots and quests. Not the case here. I was genuinely interested in the characters, settings, and quests. This game made me laugh out loud, grimace, and smile with triumph. 

Do yourself a favor and play this game if you haven't. It's incredible

183809076.review:
[h1] Um excelente jogo, mas um tanto quanto problemático. [/h1]

[h3] Resumo no final da análise. [/h3]

Fallout New Vegas é um excelente RPG em si, porém o jogo apresenta muitos problemas técnicos de desempenho e de código, problemas esses que vão desde uma queda temporária de FPS, a até mesmo crashes e corrompimento de save. O jogo é muito bem otimizado na questão gráfica, então até mesmo um notebook/PC velhinho com placa de vídeo integrada vai rodar esse jogo com uma boa taxa de quadros. (Joguei a 30 FPS numa Intel HD Graphics 3000 na época)

[h3] Mods usados: [/h3]

O uso de mods é basicamente obrigatório. Não recomendo a ninguém jogar Fallout New Vegas do jeito Vanilla que vem na steam, pois você com certeza vai ter muitos problemas. Os mods que eu usei para melhorar a minha experiência estão listados logo abaixo:

Yukichigai Unofficial Patch - YUP (Correção de bugs)
Yukichigai Unofficial Patch - YUP (Portuguese Translation - 13.2) - (Mod para fazer a tradução funcionar)
Fallout NV e DLCs PT-BR (Tradução)
NVSE - New Vegas Script Extender (Mod para instalar outros mods)
NVAC (Anti-Crash)
FNV 4GB Patcher (Permite que o jogo use até 4 GB de RAM. Padrão: 2 GB)
NVTF - New Vegas Tick Fix (Melhora o desempenho e corrige problemas de FPS alto)
Using the console doesn't disable achievements (Mod para ganhar conquistas mesmo usando o console do jogo. Explicação logo abaixo)

Obs: 1 - O mod de usar o console não melhora o desempenho do jogo, ele apenas permite que você ganhe conquistas usando o console do jogo (Local para digitar os códigos do jogo). Esse mod pode ser útil, pois eu tive um problema em uma missão em que eu tinha que entregar uma mercadoria para um NPC, só que o NPC estava fora do mapa e eu tive que usar o comando para puxar o NPC para mim, só que eu descobri que ao usar o console, o jogo desativa as conquistas. Esse mod remove essa proibição de usar console para ganhar conquistas.

2 - Todos os mods listados acima não adicionam, removem ou alteram nenhum conteúdo no jogo. Eles apenas corrigem problemas de desempenho e bugs do jogo, tirando o mod de tradução que altera o idioma.

3 - Mesmo usando todos esses mods, eu ainda tive alguns problemas com o jogo. Como por exemplo: 1 corrompimento de save, 2 ou 3 crashes, queda brutas de FPS em alguns momentos e bugs com NPCs.

[h3] Recomendações: [/h3]

Antes de jogar Fallout New vegas, é recomendado fazer algumas coisas, como por exemplo:

1 - Separar um tempo antes de começar a jogar para instalar os mods.
2 - Ter em mente que mesmo com mods, o jogo ainda pode apresentar problemas.
3 - Sempre usar o Quicksave (F5), sempre deixar o auto-save ativado no menu de opções, nunca salvar o jogo em cima de outro jogo já salvo (Foi assim que meu save corrompeu) e a cada 30 minutos ou 1 hora, salvar o jogo manualmente em um slot novo.
4 - O console pode corrigir alguns bugs (não todos) como por exemplo o do NPC da minha missão estar fora do mapa.

[h2] Resumo [/h2]

Fallout New Vegas é um excelente RPG, porém o uso de mods é basicamente obrigatório devido aos seus inúmeros problemas. O jogo tem muita coisa a oferecer e se você ja jogou outros RPGs da Bethesda, como Fallout 3/4, TES Oblivion/Skyrim e curtiu, muito provavelmente você vai gostar de Fallout New Vegas também. Recomendo.

183665387.review:
Runs well on Steam Deck out of the box with Proton.  Stable performance, accurate button prompts, reasonable default controls.  

Not recommending because it just isn't fun IMO.  At first I liked exploding heads in slow motion with VATS.  But the melee combat gets old fast.  Your attack feels the same whether you have 30 Melee or 80, and whether you have a shaving razor or a machete from Caesar's Legion.  Hard to get excited for level ups when I'm not unlocking cool new shit.  

Exploration is miserable when the character walks like a geriatric amputee and can barely climb knee-high rocks.

Quests feel unrewarding when everything seems to be a checklist within a checklist within a checklist.  Doesn't help when the compass lies by omission or doesn't actually help indoors.

183595145.review:
Fallout: New Vegas is probably my all-time favorite game and is the first game I "perfected" (got all achievements) on steam! I've played through countless playthroughs and genuinely enjoyed them all.
PROS:
- Interesting, deep, and detailed world building.
- Four different main endings to the main story.
- A variety of fun side quests.
- VATS system allows those with poor FPS reflexes to enjoy the combat as well.
- Massive modding community to enjoy the game you want to enjoy it.
- Expansive feat system and other fun RPG elements.
- Fully voiced cast with good voice acting.
NEUTRAL:
- sometimes delves into dark or mature topics
CONS:
- game crashes are regular (save often).
